question: Question_05_(d)
statement:
Let

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f(x) = \frac{2x^2}{x^2-1}\end{align*}

\textbf{(d)} Find the vertical asymptotes of $f$.
sols:
To find the vertical asymptotes, we will take the limit of the function
at both \emph{x = -1} and \emph{x = 1}.

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to -1} f(x) = \lim_{x \to -1} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1}\end{align*}

This limit is undefined since the denominator goes to zero but the
numerator is nonzero. We will try taking the left and right hand limit
at \emph{x = -1}

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to -1^-} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1} = \lim_{x \to -1^-} \frac{2x^2}{(x + 1)(x - 1)} = \infty\end{align*}

Note that as \emph{x} approaches -1 from the left, the numerator of the
fraction will be positive. Both terms in the denominator will be
negative, yielding an overall positive number. As the denominator is
decreasing, this is the same as saying that the entire fraction is
increasing. Thus the limit is positive infinity. Using similar reasoning
we can solve the right hand limit to get

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to -1^+} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1} = -\infty\end{align*}

Taking the limit at \emph{x = 1} will give us an undefined limit in the
same way as before. Checking right and left hand limits gives

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to 1^-} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1} = -\infty\end{align*}

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to 1^+} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1} = \infty\end{align*}

Thus we have vertical asymptotes at \emph{x = -1} and \emph{x = 1},
where the value of the function near the asymptote depends which side of
the asymptote it is approaching.
hints:
We check for vertical asymptotes by taking the limit of the function at
points where it is undefined or otherwise not continuous. From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/April_2012/Question_05_(a)}{part
(a)} of this question we know that the points of interest are \emph{x} =
-1 and \emph{x} = 1.
